 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
programmatic approach for the Promoting Economic Diversification Program, and (ii) a proposed 
policy-based  grant  to  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  for  subprogram  1  of  the  Promoting  Economic 
Diversification Program.  
 
2. 
The proposed program aims to support the government’s efforts to diversify the Kyrgyz 
economy gradually away from gold extraction and remittance-led consumption. The program will 
accomplish this by building on longstanding support from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for 
government-led  reforms  that  aim  to  achieve  broad-based  economic  growth  through  improving 
trade  and 
(SMEs) 
industry-linked  skills 
development,  public–private  partnership 
development.1 The programmatic approach, with two subprograms in 2019 and 2021, recognizes 
that reforms of this nature are complex and require sustained political support over election cycles 
and leadership changes, as well as a medium-term view to reform that allows institutional capacity 
to develop and implement policies, laws, and regulations in a stepwise, chronological manner.

II. 

PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 

A. 

Background and Development Constraints  

3. 
Development  context.  The  Kyrgyz  Republic  is  a  landlocked  lower  middle-income 
economy in Central Asia with a population of more than 6.3 million and estimated gross domestic 
product  (GDP)  per  capita  of  $1,255  (at  the  lower  end  of  countries  in  the  region).2 Although 
economic growth averaged 4.3% during 2000–2018, slightly above the regional average, it has 
been  volatile—reflecting  the  effect  of  exogenous  shocks,  domestic  events,  and  heavy 
dependence  on  gold  production  and  exports  (about  6%–10%  of  GDP  each  year)  and  private 
consumption based on remittance inflows (about 30% of GDP).3 The structure of the economy 
has changed since the mid-1990s, with significant impacts on labor market dynamics, especially 
formal and informal employment, and job creation. Agriculture’s share of GDP, for example, more 
than halved from 2000 to 2016, falling from 36.6% to 14.4%, with excess labor either migrating to 
low-skilled  jobs  abroad,  especially  to  the  Russian  Federation  and  Kazakhstan,  or  moving  to 
informal jobs in the main urban centers of Bishkek and Osh. On the other hand, the services share 
has doubled over the same period, rising from 32.1% to 57.3%, driven mainly by large remittance 
flows into construction, real estate, and trade.4 The unemployment rate has been relatively high, 
about 7%–8% in recent years, though the extent of underemployment has improved somewhat. 
Currently, about half of employees are in services, 29% are in agriculture, and about 21% are in 
industry  and  construction.  In  2018,  women  constituted  30.0%  of  managers  of  small  firms  and 
41.0% of managers of medium-sized firms, 34.9% of individual entrepreneurs were women, and 
19.2% of agricultural enterprises were headed by women. The lack of start-up capital presents a

 barrier to entry into entrepreneurship for both men and women, but women face gender-specific 
barriers.  In  addition,  most  of  the  population  lives  just  above  the  poverty  line  although  poverty 
levels  have  declined  significantly. 5 The  government  aims  to  increase  the  economy’s  growth 
potential. Its national development agenda, including the National Development Strategy of the 
Kyrgyz  Republic  for  2018–2040  (NDS  2040),  has  focused  on  decreasing  the  country’s 
dependence on migration-led remittances and gold extraction.6 The government recognizes that 
this is an ambitious medium- to long-term reform agenda and has requested ADB’s analytical, 
technical, and financial support.  
 
4. 
Macroeconomic performance. Economic growth slowed in 2018 in tandem with smaller 
gains in mining and manufacturing. According to the 2019 Asian Development Outlook, growth is 
projected to recover in 2019 and continue accelerating in 2020 on recovery in gold production 
and continued growth in the region (footnote 3). The March 2019 Article IV consultations of the 
International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  concluded  that  the  country’s  macroeconomic  and  fiscal 
situation was stable, but emphasized the importance of improving the business climate and rule 
of law to put the economy on a higher and more inclusive growth path. The IMF recommended 
cementing  macroeconomic  stability  and  building  buffers  by  ensuring  the  fiscal  deficit does  not 
exceed 2.5% of GDP in the medium term.7 In line with this recommendation, the government’s 
fiscal deficit target is 1.7% of GDP for 2019 and 1.4% of GDP for 2020.8 
 
Core development problems. The government and development partners recognize that 
5. 
economic  diversification  will  be  a  gradual  process  and  that,  in  the  short  term,  the  country’s 
development will continue to rely on gold extraction and remittances. Under the NDS 2040, a new 
inclusive,  broad-based,  and  sustainable  development  model  is  being  implemented  to  help  the 
transition to a dynamic, globally oriented, market economy. Under this model, the agriculture and 
manufacturing  sectors  will  be  reenergized  to  avoid  the  heavy  reliance  on  remittance-driven 
services. The government will prioritize improving the business climate and overcoming corruption. 
Reforms  addressed  through  the  Promoting  Economic  Diversification  Program  will  help  the 
government  achieve  (i)  increased  foreign  trade  and  improved  movement  of  labor,  capital,  and 
services  to  the  European  Union  (EU)  and  Eurasian  Economic  Union  (EEU);  (ii)  a  competitive 
business  environment 
that  supports  SME  development  and  entrepreneurship;  (iii)  a 
comprehensive  approach  to  developing  and  implementing  bankable  PPP  projects;  and  (iv) 
stronger links between the education system and the labor market through demand-driven and 
learning  outcomes-based  curricula.  The  program  will  help  address  the  following  core, 
interconnected development constraints. 9 
  
Weak  trade  and  foreign  direct  investment  competitiveness.  In  2017,  foreign  trade 
6. 
totaled $6.3 billion, up 12.5% from 2016. However, exports were concentrated on a few products 
(mainly  precious  metals  and  mineral  commodities  and  three  major  markets  [Kazakhstan,  the 
Russian Federation, and Switzerland]). Several agricultural  products  have  considerable  export

 potential.10 Significant  scope  also  exists  to  improve  the  country’s  utilization  rate  under  the  EU 
Generalised  Scheme  of  Preferences  plus.  In  addition,  despite  a  relatively  open  foreign  direct 
investment (FDI) regime, the sources of FDI remain concentrated in a few countries (mainly the 
Russian Federation). Policy and institutional reforms are needed to (i) improve the policy, legal, 
and  regulatory  environment  for  trade  and  business,  including  access  to  trade  and  market 
intelligence; (ii) strengthen the capacity of local laboratories; (iii) streamline and simplify the export 
process;  and  (iv)  strengthen  the  capacity  of  SMEs  to  comply  with  international  market  access 
requirements.11 Laws are in line with standards but are not being applied consistently, which is 
deterring foreign investors.12 13  
 
7. 
Limited small and medium-sized enterprise development. In 2017, SMEs employed 
only 2% of the economically active population and their share of GDP was 11% (compared with 
50% and 60% for large firms). The SME share of gross value added in GDP shows that, in 2016, 
large firms and individual entrepreneurs contributed more value addition to GDP than SMEs.14 
This low level of productivity undermines the capacity of SMEs to be regionally competitive and 
to integrate successfully into regional and global value chains.15 Access to EU and EEU markets 
will require higher and more consistent volumes and compliance with quality standards, which 
could transform the sector, accelerate the shift to the formal economy, and increase value addition. 
Contributing factors the program will help address include (i) overlapping laws and regulations 
and fragmented institutions, (ii) the high cost of credit, (iii) lack of long-term financial products and 
instruments,  (iv)  lack  of  incentives  for  SMEs  to  formalize  and  adhere  to  labor  laws,  (v) 
overregulation in some sectors, and (vi) high taxes on wages. 16  
 
8. 
Lack  of  infrastructure  and  public–private  partnership  investments.  The  quality  of 
infrastructure in the Kyrgyz Republic is among the lowest in the world. The Kyrgyz Republic ranks 
107 out of 140 countries with regard to overall infrastructure quality.17 Since its first PPP law in 
2012, it has continued to expand and define its policy through bylaws and regulations, including 
a  2016  amendment. 18  The  country  has  made  significant  progress.  In  2018,  The  Economist 
Intelligence Unit Infrascope assessment report ranked the Kyrgyz Republic 9th out of 19 Asian 
countries and 1st in Central Asia,19 but noted slow implementation of PPP projects.20 The main 
factors include (i) lack of interest of the partners in initiating projects, (ii) limited PPP sensitization 
and  awareness,  (iii)  slow  expansion  of  the  PPP  pipeline,  (iv) ineffective  gateway  reviews,  (v) 
limited access to nonrecourse finance, and (vi) limited attention to the gender and social impact

9. 
Weak links between skills development and industry needs. The labor market of the 
Kyrgyz Republic is characterized by skilled workers and technicians from the Soviet era who are 
approaching  retirement.  The  current  technical  and  vocational  education  and  training  (TVET) 
system is not able to meet the labor force replacement rate, which is up to five times higher than 
the number of skilled workers entering the workforce.22 The government recognizes that workers 
who are unprepared for the changing skills requirements are less likely to find employment and 
more likely to be in volatile, low wage jobs. In the absence of a national qualifications system and 
national  qualifications  framework,  unstructured  TVET  system  variations  have  developed.  The 
quality and relevance of vocational education thus requires attention. Innovative TVET finance 
reforms are needed to accompany increased enrollment and graduation, such as the introduction 
of  per  capita  financing  (PCF)  and  incentive  funds  to  improve  administration  and  operations.23 
Vocational  education  enrollment  has  a  gender  imbalance,  with  57%  female  and  43%  male 
students,24 but gender  stereotypes  affect  the  choice  of  subject. For example, women  and  girls 
continue to choose traditionally female-dominated fields: education (87%), humanities and social 
sciences (75%), and services (67%). Specific measures, such as revising qualification standards 
to eliminate gender stereotypes and discrimination in competencies, qualifications, and curricula, 
are needed to create an enabling environment for the enrollment of girls in nontraditional fields of 
education.25 
 
10. 
ADB’s  past  engagement  in  the  sector.  ADB  has  been  helping  the  government  with 
critical  structural  reforms  to  help  diversify  the  economy  since  2007  (Figure).  Despite  many 
challenges, including macroeconomic shocks and two major political crises that have absorbed 
administrative effort and slowed reform implementation, ADB-supported reforms have resulted in 
significant  improvements  in  policies  and  institutions.  These  include  (i)  reduced  tax  compliance 
costs 
tax  declarations, 
(ii) automated  pre-customs  clearance  processes  through  the  single  window  for  foreign  trade, 
(iii) improved  access  to  finance  by  reducing  credit  risks  and  making  new  products  available, 
(iv) increased SME access to finance through establishing and capitalizing a guarantee fund that 
covers part of a loan’s default risk and motivates lenders to extend credit to groups that would not 
have access to finance under normal circumstances, (v) a strengthened institutional framework 
for  market-driven  skills  development,  and  (vi)  an  improved  enabling  environment  for  PPPs.26  
Biennial country performance assessments have shown improvements in the quality of policies 
and institutions as a result of ADB policy-based lending programs. The Kyrgyz Republic performs 
well above the average for ADB’s Group A developing member countries for structural policies

11. 
Lessons. Key lessons from past interventions and ADB’s experience with policy-based 
lending  in  Central  Asia  and  other  regions  have  been  incorporated  into  the  program  design.28 
These include the following:  

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

ADB should continue to support investment climate reforms and simultaneously 
expand the portfolio of private sector investments and PPPs. In particular, the use 
of  long-term  programmatic  assistance  and 
technical  assistance  (TA)  is 
recommended to support the medium-term view to reform.  
ADB  should  develop  guidelines  and  templates  for  preparing  blueprints  for 
institutional reforms since these are critical for the successful implementation of 
policy-based loans.  
Government and ADB should pursue a small number of critical and realistic policy 
actions to help ensure the reform program can be carried out effectively and that 
implementing agencies’ technical staff remain fully connected to the process. 

Building on lessons learned, subprogram 2 will include a post-partnership engagement framework 
that would enable a working-level commitment to jointly prepare the next phase of associated, 
and more substantive, reforms to support the programs sustainability beyond 2021.  
 
B. 

Policy Reform and ADB’s Value Addition 

12. 
Alignment with NSDS 2040 and ADB strategic engagement. The NDS 2040 aims to 
create  a  strong  economy,  ensure  high  quality  of  life,  develop  competitive  human  capital,  and 
contribute to regional cooperation. The country’s medium-term strategy for 2018–2022 has four 
priorities: (i) raising the well-being of the nation by promoting macroeconomic stability, improving

 6 

connectivity with regional markets, creating a conducive investment policy, and implementing a 
program for SMEs; (ii) developing agriculture and industry focusing on diversification, in addition 
to key sectors such as energy, transport, mining, tourism, textiles, and construction; (iii) enhancing 
human development outcomes and deepening unity among ethnic groups; and (iv) undertaking 
public administration reforms to improve service delivery.29 The program is closely aligned with 
the objectives of these medium- and long-term national development strategies and the country 
partnership strategy, 2018–2022 for the Kyrgyz Republic. It is also consistent with ADB’s Strategy 
2030  and  its  focus  on  strengthening  governance  and  institutional  capacity  through  supporting 
public  management  reforms  and  financial  sustainability,  improving  infrastructure  and  service 
delivery, and strengthening capacity and standards.30 Subprogram 1 comprises 12 policy actions, 
all  of  which  have  been  accomplished.  All  subprogram  2  actions  are  indicative  and  subject  to 
further discussion with Government. 
 
13. 
Reform  area  1:  Trade  and  investment  competitiveness  to  develop  non-mineral 
sector and diversify exports and investments improved. The actions under this reform area 
aim to develop the agriculture and manufacturing sectors, and diversify exports and types and 
sources of FDI. Under subprogram 1, the government approved the national Food Security and 
Nutrition Program, 2019–2023 to improve the country’s nutritional status, ensure consistency of 
food  supply  in  the  domestic  market,  and  guarantee  compliance  with  export  market  consumer 
quality and consumer protection standards. The Food Security and Nutrition Program envisions 
special  measures  to  ensure  that  (i)  women  producers  have  access  to  finance;  (ii)  businesses 
where  women  dominate,  such  as  poultry  and  dairy,  are prioritized  for  support;  (iii)  women  are 
involved in the management of pastures; and (iv) special measures on nutrition targeting for girls 
and women of reproductive age, infants, and children are introduced. The government approved 
the Creation and Development of Trade and Logistics Centers for Agricultural Products Program 
2019–2023 to reduce storage, distribution, and transport costs for agricultural producers. Ministry 
of  Economy  implemented  the  Export  Development  Program,  2019–2023  by  (i)  designating  a 
dedicated body to administer the Registration of Export System for exporting to the EU within the 
framework of the Generalized System of Preferences plus (or GSP+), which provides preferential 
market access; (ii) obtaining the International Laboratory Accreditation Cooperation for the Kyrgyz 
Center of Accreditation to enhance product standardization and compliance with EU and EEU 
market access conditions; (iii) signing an agreement with the Islamic Development Bank on the 
preparation  of  feasibility  study  to  establish  the  integrated  supply  chain  park  for  Halal  product 
development and export; and (iv) the Kyrgyz Center of Accreditation obtaining the status of a full 
member of the International Forum on Halal Accreditation. To enhance the enabling environment 
for  promoting  FDI,  the  government  adopted  and  implemented  an  action  plan  to  improve  the 
country’s ranking in the annual Doing Business survey, a benchmark used by foreign companies 
as a decision-making tool in evaluating and pricing the risks of investing in developing countries.31 
The  International  Civil  Aviation  Organization,  a  United  Nations  agency,  introduced  the  Fifth 
Freedom of the Air rules and regulations. These will liberalize the aviation sector and help develop 
tourism, trade, and transport logistics industries by allowing more international airlines to operate 
in the Kyrgyz Republic, thus helping to lower business costs for exporters.32

 Subprogram  2  will  build  on  these  improvements  in  the  enabling  and  operational 
14. 
environment and support the government to implement high-priority follow-on reforms, including 
(i) the approval of the law on organic agricultural production, which will provide the legal basis for 
the production, certification, and regulation of organic agricultural products; (ii) the establishment 
of at least two trade and logistics centers; (iii) the annual allocation of at least Som250 million for 
the implementation of projects for financing export-oriented enterprises; and (iv) becoming a party 
to the World Trade Organization’s Agreement on Government Procurement, which will allow firms 
to bid for foreign government tender contracts. 
 
15. 
Reform  area  2:  Small  and  medium-sized  enterprise  development  to  broaden  the 
economic base and promote entrepreneurship improved. The actions under this reform area 
aim  to  broaden  the  economic  base  and  promote  entrepreneurship.  Under  subprogram  1,  the 
government improved SME access to finance and services through (i) Parliamentary approval of 
the Law on Guarantee Funds 2019 to determine the authorized body for regulating the activities 
of guarantee funds; (ii) the National Bank of the Kyrgyz Republic (NBKR) approval of a capital 
increase for the Guarantee Fund by up to 49% (about Som500 million); and (iii) NBKR approval 
of changes to its regulatory requirements to increase access to financing by optimizing collateral 
requirements  for  the  provision  of  loans,  establishing  a  credit  rating  system,  and  introducing 
electronic signatures for online lending to improve financial intermediation. MOE approved the 
Concept for Development of Business Service Centers for 2019–2022. The centers will serve as 
a central contact point for SMEs and provide services including obtaining approvals for permits, 
licenses  and,  patents;  capacity  building  and  training;  legal  and  marketing  services;  trade  and 
logistics support; and loans and other financial instruments for SMEs and entrepreneurs. 
 
16. 
Subprogram  2  will  build  on  these  improvements  in  the  enabling  and  operational 
environment and support the government to implement high-priority follow-on reforms, including 
(i)  developing  an  infrastructure  connection  system—electricity,  water,  and  sewage—with  a 
standardized and transparent connection schedule and corresponding fees; (ii) implementing a 
system  for  issuing  electronic  permits,  licenses,  and  patents;  and  (iii)  NBKR  adopting  new 
regulations  on  mobile  financial  services  to  expand  access  to  alternative  forms  of  payment  for 
SMEs. 
  
17. 
Reform  area  3:  Public–private  partnership  to  develop  social  and  economic 
infrastructure improved. The actions under this reform area aim to develop critical social and 
economic infrastructure. PPP will allow the government to accelerate infrastructure investment 
and  deliver  infrastructure  services  more  efficiently.  Under  subprogram 1,  MOE  published  five 
tenders for consulting services for preparing PPP projects, including feasibility studies and tender 
documents, and completed and approved two ongoing feasibility studies. The completion of these 
consultancy  services  and  feasibility  studies  will  strengthen  the  pipeline  of  PPP  projects  and 
emphasize the need for sound project preparation. The Ministry of Economy (MOE) adopted a 
PPP  manual,  which  includes  model  tender  documents  and  gender-sensitive  operational 
guidelines on the identification, preparation, and implementation of PPP projects. This will provide 
operational  guidance  and  ensure  proper  project  governance,  sound  project  preparation, 
transparent  procurement  of  projects,  and  efficient  monitoring  of  PPP  arrangements.  The 
government approved the establishment and operationalization of the Center for Public–Private 
Partnership,  with  budgetary  allocation  of  Som7  million  for  2019  to  support  and  accelerate  the 
development  of  PPP  projects.  The  center  is  essential  for  ensuring  successful  PPPs,  as  it  will 
promote  PPP;  provide  TA  and  quality  control  for  the  identification,  preparation,  and 

7 

 

 implementation of PPP projects; and disseminate knowledge on PPP and support the necessary 
capacity building.33 
 
18. 
Subprogram  2  will  build  on  these  improvements  in  the  enabling  and  operational 
environment and support the government to implement high-priority follow-on reforms, including 
(i) budgetary allocation of Som14 million each for 2020 and 2021 for the operations of the Center 
for PPPs, (ii) the publication of at least 10 tenders for consulting services to prepare PPP projects 
and issuance of the request for qualification for at least three PPP projects, and (iii) the approval 
of  the  PPP  Development  Program,  2021–2026  to  continue  the  government’s  approach  to 
developing  PPP  projects  by  focusing  on  institutional  checks  and  balances,  strengthening 
institutional capacity, and operationalizing financial instruments. 

 
Reform  area  4:  Industry-linked  skills  development  through  enhanced  internal 
19. 
efficiency and qualifications structure improved. The actions under this reform area aim to 
promote economic diversification and productivity by improving the quality and relevance of the 
current and future workforce. Under subprogram 1, (i) Ministry of Education introduced PCF in 
primary vocational education (PVE) institutions to improve the efficient allocation of funds to the 
subsector, that is, funding is based on the actual cost of competency-based teaching for given 
occupations and enrollment numbers in contrast to the historic lump-sum allocations when PVE 
institutions based their costing largely on the approved budgets of previous years; and (ii) Ministry 
of Education established incentive funds in each PVE institution under PCF, which allow flexible 
and  performance-related  remuneration  of  PVE  staff  and  occupation-differentiated  provision  of 
consumables  and  supplies.  A  legislative  foundation  is  provided  for  the  national  qualifications 
system, including the national qualifications framework, to improve the matching of qualifications’ 
supply and demand. The Agency of Vocational Education (AVE) has developed and approved 
the model center guidelines and an action plan that provides for model centers to be established 
in  the  form  of  legal  entities  to  offer  work-based  learning  opportunities  and  gradually  carry  out 
entrepreneurial activities to generate and retain income. A partially self-funding TVET institution 
is  better  able  to  fulfil  its  mandate  of  delivering  improved  and  more  relevant  education  and 
employability outcomes. 
 
20. 
Subprogram 2 will build on these improvements and support (i) rolling out the PCF scheme 
and incentive funds system-wide in TVET; (ii)  developing and approving a coherent methodology 
of  competencies,  qualifications,  and  curricula  in  at  least  three  priority  sectors  for  economic 
diversification; and (iii) establishing all established model centers (three outside Bishkek) as legal 
entities and making them fully operational, in accordance with the approved AVE guidelines and 
action plan.  

 
21. 
ADB’s  value  addition.  ADB’s  experience  and  strong  relationship  with  the  government 
played  an  important  role  in  identifying  and  implementing  critical  reforms  (footnote  26).  Strong 
value  addition  is  demonstrated  through  (i)  identifying  possible  policy,  legal,  and  institutional 
solutions  and  international  good  practices;  (ii)  conducting  policy  dialogue  and  generating 
knowledge  products  such  as  diagnostic  studies;  and  (iii)  having  long-standing  experience  in 
designing  and  implementing  TA  and  policy-based  loans  in  support  of  economic  diversification 
reforms (footnotes 1, 26-27). Developing and implementing reforms in the program would have 
been difficult and costly without ADB’s analytical, technical, and financial support. 

 

 

33 Capacity building will continue to feature in ADB’s support, given the technical nature of preparing and implementing 

PPP and the introduction of the ADB-supported Certified PPP Professional Program. 

8 

 

 

 Development  partner  coordination.  Although  no  other  development  partners  are 
22. 
providing general budget support in 2019, support for the government’s economic diversification 
efforts continues through policy dialogue and TA.34 ADB has closely coordinated the development 
of the program with development partners’ interventions.35 Coordination and consultation with the 
IMF has been  particularly strong. The IMF, through  its resident representative in Bishkek, has 
formally expressed support for the program and welcomed its scope and coverage given the focus 
on  structural  reforms,  which  will  help  reduce  the  economy’s  reliance  on  gold  extraction  and 
remittances. Budget support grants from ADB and other development partners will help ensure 
that the government is able to build room for significant infrastructure investments and stabilize 
public debt over the medium term, which is consistent with the IMF’s policy advice (footnote 7). 
 
C. 

Impacts of the Reform 

23. 
The  country’s  overarching  development  objective  is  to  create  jobs  and  provide  decent 
employment and stable income for people. The effect of the reforms supported under the program 
will  be  the  achievement  of  broad-based  economic  growth.  These  reforms  will  primarily  work 
through four transmission channels: (i) the agriculture sector developed, exports diversified, and 
domestic and foreign investments increased; (ii) entrepreneurship promoted and the economic 
base  broadened  through  increased  SME  access  to  formal  financial  services,  products,  and 
business  support  services;  (iii)  the  quality  and  pace  of  PPP  project  selection,  screening,  and 
preparation improved; and (iv) economic productivity improved through skills development linked 
to industry needs.36  
 
D. 

Development Financing Needs and Budget Support 

24. 
The government has requested two grants not exceeding $100.0 million, comprising $50.0 
million each for Subprograms 1 and 2 from ADB’s Special Funds resources (Asian Development 
Fund)  to  help  finance  the  program.  The  program  will  help  the  government  to  meet  its  total 
financing requirements from 2019 to 2021, which are estimated at $429.3 million.37 The remaining 
gap will be filled by external financing ($30.0 million in general budget support from the Russian 
Federation  and  concessional  project  loans)  and  domestic  borrowing.  ADB  determined  the 
proposed grant size after considering the government’s commitment to economic diversification 
reforms, the country’s development financing needs, and the availability of financing from other 
development partners. 
 
E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

25. 
The MOE is the executing agency for the program. The MOE, Ministry of Finance, Ministry 
of  Agriculture,  Ministry  of  Education,  and  NBKR  are  the  implementing  agencies.  The  program 
implementation  period  is  August  2018–July  2021,  with  subprogram  1  being  implemented  from 
August 2018 to July 2019. Subprogram 2 is expected to be implemented from August 2019 to 
July  2021.  The  proceeds  of  the  policy-based  grant  will  be  withdrawn  upon  effectiveness  in 
accordance with ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook (2017, as amended from time to time).38

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

 
26. 
Following ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the program is classified category C 
for the environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples. Program activities will be 
confined  to  policy  and  institutional  reforms.  No  activity  will  result  in  or  lead  to  involuntary 
resettlement, or negatively affect indigenous peoples or the environment. In addition, the program 
is  classified  effective  gender  mainstreaming.  It  supports  the  improvement  of  gender  outcomes 
across all four key reform areas. 
 
27. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  MOE.  ADB  completed  a  governance  risk  assessment  in  2018  according  to  the 
implementation guidelines of ADB’s Second Governance and Anticorruption Action Plan.39 The 
assessment  found  that  the  country’s  public  financial  management  and  public  procurement 
systems were functioning well overall. The government, with support from development partners 
such as the IMF, the World Bank, and EU, is making a concerted effort to address weaknesses 
in these systems through iterative reform strategies and action plans. Major risks and mitigating 
measures  are  summarized  in  detail  in  the  risk  assessment  and  risk  management  plan.40 To 
mitigate  the  risks,  the  program  focuses  on  areas  where  the  government  has  a  strong  record 
(paras. 10-11) and has selected options for policy actions from the NDS 2040 that would help 
maintain  reform  momentum  beyond  2021  (footnotes  6  and  28),  and  where  ADB  TA  has  been 
deployed to supplement the technical capacity of the implementing agencies to ensure that priority 
reforms are implemented.41  
 

IV. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

28. 
The government has assured ADB that implementation of the program shall conform to 
all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the grant 
agreement. As a condition to the effectiveness, all policy actions completed by the government 
as specified in the policy matrix relating to the program will have to continue to be in effect. 
 

V.
